text: [music playing]

BETHANY JEAN CLEMENT: Hi, I'm
Bethany Jean Clement, food
writer at "The Seattle Times."

Here in the Pacific
Northwest, we're

known for our incredible
local seafood.

There's also amazing farmland
very close to Seattle.

And I'm going to take
you to three of my very
favorite restaurants.

We're going to start
off with some meat,
here at Dot's Butcher & Deli.

Dot's is one of my very
favorite places in Seattle

because it epitomizes
local food in a way
that not very many places do.

Miles James, the
proprietor here,

has his own porchetta recipe
that is just outstanding.

And it beats the pants
off any other porchetta
you're gonna get anywhere.

MILES JAMES: For the sandwich,
we roast it ahead of time
and take the skin off.

And then re-bake that so it gets
really crispy in the cracklins.

Slice it really thin and heat
it up in the convection oven.

And then put a pretty
vinegary coleslaw on it

because the acid of the coleslaw
balances the fat of porchetta.

And an herb aioli that's got
a fair amount of tarragon
in it on a ciabatta roll.

BETHANY JEAN CLEMENT:
Le Pichet serves

very classic French
food, so it may

seem funny that my
very favorite dish
is just a simple, green salad.

But this salad
transcends salad-ness.
It's always super fresh.
It's very simple.

The dressing-- well, I'll leave
the secret of the dressing
to chef Jim Drohman to explain.

JIM DROHMAN: The
most requested recipe

we have is for our salade
verte, so you're not
the only person who likes it.

But I think the one
ingredient that people

would not have guessed was in
there is reduced orange juice.

BETHANY JEAN
CLEMENT: Bar Melusine

and it's adjoining
restaurant Bateau

are both run by
chef Renee Erickson

and she is a total
local food hero.

Recently, she was given
not just a James Beard

Award, but a Rock
Star Chef Award
from "Rolling Stone Magazine."

One of the things that I love
to get here besides a dozen

or more oysters
on the half shell

is the mini version of the
amazing Bateau hamburger.
LAUREN KENNEY: Of course.
So, understandable.

BETHANY JEAN
CLEMENT: I have heard

that the actual hamburger
patty is basted in butter
the entire time it's cooking.
True or false?
[sizzling]
LAUREN KENNEY: True.
BETHANY JEAN CLEMENT: Yes.
[chuckles]
[sizzling]

LAUREN KENNEY: Nothing
wrong with a lot of butter.

BETHANY JEAN CLEMENT:
Butter makes it better.
Thank you so much.

A beautiful plate of
oysters like this epitomizes

what's incredible about dining
out in Seattle and our Pacific
Northwest cuisine.
Here's to you.
